reasoning:
The learning outcomes for Extending Patterns in Mathematics will progressively develop students' ability to recognize, create, and analyze patterns from simple repetitive sequences to more complex algebraic relationships. The progression will focus on developing spatial, numerical, and logical reasoning skills that are fundamental to algebraic thinking.

Key developmental considerations:
- Junior and Senior Infants: Focus on basic pattern recognition and simple repetitive patterns
- First and Second Class: Introduce more complex pattern creation and basic pattern rules
- Third and Fourth Class: Develop skills in describing and extending patterns with increasing complexity
- Fifth and Sixth Class: Introduce algebraic thinking and more abstract pattern relationships

The outcomes will build cognitive skills such as:
- Visual pattern recognition
- Sequential thinking
- Logical reasoning
- Abstract mathematical thinking
- Pattern prediction and extension

learning_outcomes.description: Identify and continue simple repeating patterns using concrete materials and visual representations
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic understanding of sorting and matching

learning_outcomes.description: Create and describe repeating patterns using color, shape, and size with increasing complexity
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic pattern recognition skills

learning_outcomes.description: Recognize and extend numerical patterns involving addition and subtraction within 20
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of basic number sequences

learning_outcomes.description: Analyze and predict the next terms in growing numerical and geometric patterns
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Ability to recognize pattern rules

learning_outcomes.description: Investigate and describe the underlying rules of complex numerical and geometric patterns
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of pattern extension and prediction

learning_outcomes.description: Generate and solve simple algebraic pattern problems using variables and unknown quantities
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced pattern recognition and rule identification

learning_outcomes.description: Create and analyze complex recursive and linear patterns, explaining the relationship between terms
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced understanding of pattern rules and algebraic thinking

learning_outcomes.description: Apply algebraic reasoning to solve multi-step pattern problems and generalize pattern rules using symbolic representations
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Complex pattern analysis and algebraic thinking skills

reasoning: The learning outcomes for Number Patterns and Sequences will progressively develop students' understanding of mathematical relationships, pattern recognition, and logical thinking. The progression will focus on increasing complexity, from simple visual and concrete patterns to more abstract and algebraic thinking. Each year will build upon the previous year's skills, introducing more sophisticated pattern identification, prediction, and manipulation techniques.

learning_outcomes.description: Recognize and continue simple repeating patterns using concrete materials and visual representations
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic counting skills and understanding of sequence

learning_outcomes.description: Create and describe simple linear patterns involving 2-3 elements using colors, shapes, or objects
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Ability to recognize basic repeating patterns

learning_outcomes.description: Identify and extend number patterns involving addition and subtraction within 20
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of basic addition and subtraction

learning_outcomes.description: Recognize, describe, and generate numeric sequences with consistent intervals (skip counting by 2s, 3s, 5s, 10s)
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic multiplication concepts and number sense

learning_outcomes.description: Analyze and predict terms in increasing and decreasing numeric sequences using algebraic reasoning
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of multiplication and division

learning_outcomes.description: Create and solve problems involving complex numeric patterns and sequences with multiple operations
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced understanding of arithmetic operations

learning_outcomes.description: Use algebraic notation to represent and generalize numeric patterns, identifying rules and relationships
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Complex pattern recognition and algebraic thinking

learning_outcomes.description: Develop and apply sophisticated strategies to analyze, predict, and generate complex numeric and geometric sequences
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced algebraic reasoning and pattern manipulation skills

reasoning: The learning outcomes for Number sentences and equations will progressively develop students' understanding of algebraic thinking, starting with simple number relationships and gradually moving towards more complex equation solving. The progression will focus on building foundational skills, introducing symbolic representations, and developing problem-solving abilities across primary school years.

learning_outcomes.description: Recognize and complete simple number patterns using concrete materials and visual representations
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic counting and number recognition skills

learning_outcomes.description: Create and describe simple number patterns involving addition and subtraction within 10
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of number patterns from Junior Infants

learning_outcomes.description: Use missing number symbols to represent unknown values in simple addition and subtraction number sentences
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic addition and subtraction skills

learning_outcomes.description: Solve simple number sentences with one unknown using mental strategies and basic algebraic reasoning
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of number sentences with missing symbols

learning_outcomes.description: Create and solve number sentences involving multiplication and division with one unknown
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Multiplication and division facts

learning_outcomes.description: Develop and solve two-step number sentences using variables and basic algebraic operations
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of single-step number sentences

learning_outcomes.description: Apply algebraic thinking to solve complex number sentences with multiple operations and variables
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Two-step number sentence solving skills

learning_outcomes.description: Analyze and solve multi-step algebraic equations, demonstrating advanced problem-solving and symbolic manipulation skills
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Complex algebraic reasoning from previous years

reasoning:
The learning outcomes for the Chance strand in Mathematics will progressively develop students' understanding of probability, randomness, and basic statistical reasoning. The progression will focus on introducing age-appropriate concepts of likelihood, prediction, and simple probability experiences that build from concrete, observable experiences to more abstract reasoning.

Key developmental considerations:
- Junior and Senior Infants: Focus on concrete, sensory-based experiences with chance
- First and Second Class: Introduce basic language of probability and simple experiments
- Third and Fourth Class: Begin systematic exploration of probability concepts
- Fifth and Sixth Class: Develop more sophisticated probabilistic thinking and data interpretation

learning_outcomes.description: Explore and identify simple chance events through play-based activities using descriptive language like 'might happen', 'could happen', and 'unlikely'
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic understanding of everyday language

learning_outcomes.description: Recognize and describe the likelihood of simple events occurring using terms like 'certain', 'possible', and 'impossible'
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic language skills from Junior Infants

learning_outcomes.description: Conduct simple chance experiments using coins, dice, or spinners and record basic outcomes
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of basic probability language

learning_outcomes.description: Compare the probability of different events and represent simple probability using fraction-based language (e.g., 1 out of 2, 1 out of 6)
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic understanding of simple experiments and outcomes

learning_outcomes.description: Design and conduct probability experiments, predict outcomes, and explain the concept of fairness in chance events
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Experience with basic probability experiments

learning_outcomes.description: Analyze probability scenarios, calculate simple probability percentages, and interpret the likelihood of complex events
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of experimental probability and fractions

learning_outcomes.description: Apply probabilistic reasoning to real-world scenarios, understand theoretical and experimental probability, and critically evaluate chance events
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced understanding of probability concepts

learning_outcomes.description: Develop complex probabilistic models, use advanced probability language, and apply statistical reasoning to make informed predictions and decisions
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Comprehensive understanding of probability concepts

reasoning:
The learning outcomes for Data recognition and interpretation will progressively develop students' skills in understanding, collecting, organizing, and analyzing data. The progression will focus on increasing complexity of data representation, interpretation, and critical thinking skills appropriate to each developmental stage.

Key developmental considerations:
- Junior and Senior Infants: Basic recognition and sorting
- First and Second Class: Simple data collection and representation
- Third and Fourth Class: More complex data representation and basic interpretation
- Fifth and Sixth Class: Advanced data analysis, multiple representations, and critical thinking about data

learning_outcomes.description: Sort and categorize objects by a single observable attribute (color, shape, size)
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic understanding of basic attributes

learning_outcomes.description: Create and interpret simple pictographs using concrete objects or drawings
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Ability to sort and categorize objects

learning_outcomes.description: Collect and record data using tally charts and simple bar graphs
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of basic data representation

learning_outcomes.description: Read and interpret bar graphs and pictographs, answering simple questions about the data
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Experience with creating basic graphs

learning_outcomes.description: Create and interpret line graphs and more complex bar graphs with multiple categories
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of basic graph types and data representation

learning_outcomes.description: Analyze and compare different graphical representations of the same data set, discussing strengths and limitations
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Experience with multiple graph types

learning_outcomes.description: Design and conduct surveys, create comprehensive data displays, and draw evidence-based conclusions
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced data collection and representation skills

learning_outcomes.description: Critically evaluate data sources, interpret complex statistical representations, and make predictive inferences
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced data analysis and interpretation skills

reasoning: The learning outcomes for Data representation and interpretation will progressively develop students' skills in collecting, organizing, and analyzing data. The progression will focus on increasing complexity of data handling, from simple sorting and counting in early years to more sophisticated graphing and statistical reasoning in later years. The outcomes will build mathematical literacy, critical thinking, and data interpretation skills appropriate to each developmental stage.

learning_outcomes.description: Sort and classify objects by a single attribute (color, shape, or size) and create simple pictorial representations
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic understanding of sorting and matching

learning_outcomes.description: Collect and record simple data using tally marks and create basic pictographs with concrete materials
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Ability to sort and classify objects

learning_outcomes.description: Create and interpret simple bar graphs and pictographs using whole numbers, and discuss basic data patterns
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of tally marks and basic data collection

learning_outcomes.description: Collect, organize, and represent data using bar graphs and simple tables, and draw basic conclusions from the data
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Experience with creating pictographs and bar graphs

learning_outcomes.description: Create and interpret line graphs and more complex bar graphs, calculate and use mode, median, and range in data sets
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of basic graph creation and data representation

learning_outcomes.description: Design and conduct surveys, create sophisticated data displays including pie charts, and analyze data using multiple statistical measures
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Experience with line graphs and basic statistical concepts

learning_outcomes.description: Interpret complex data sets, create advanced statistical representations, and use probability concepts to analyze data trends
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced understanding of graphing and statistical methods

learning_outcomes.description: Critically analyze multi-variable data sets, create comprehensive data reports, and use advanced statistical reasoning to draw nuanced conclusions
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Comprehensive knowledge of data representation and statistical analysis

reasoning:
The learning outcomes for the Area strand will progressively develop students' understanding of spatial measurement, starting from basic recognition and comparison in early years to more complex calculation and problem-solving in later years. The progression will focus on developing spatial reasoning, measurement skills, and mathematical thinking related to area.

Key developmental considerations:
- Early years (Infants): Introduce basic spatial concepts through concrete, hands-on experiences
- Lower primary (1st-2nd): Begin comparing and estimating areas using non-standard units
- Middle primary (3rd-4th): Introduce standard units and basic area calculations
- Upper primary (5th-6th): Develop more advanced area calculation skills and problem-solving strategies

learning_outcomes.description: Recognize and compare the size of simple shapes using direct comparison
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic understanding of big and small

learning_outcomes.description: Use non-standard units to estimate and measure the area of simple flat surfaces
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Ability to compare sizes and use basic measuring tools

learning_outcomes.description: Measure and compare areas of regular shapes using non-standard and simple standard units (e.g., square tiles)
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of measurement and basic shape recognition

learning_outcomes.description: Calculate the area of rectangles and squares using standard units (cm²) and understand the relationship between length and width
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic multiplication skills and understanding of rectangular shapes

learning_outcomes.description: Calculate the area of more complex regular shapes, including triangles and parallelograms using standard formulas
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Ability to calculate area of rectangles and basic algebraic understanding

learning_outcomes.description: Solve multi-step area problems involving irregular shapes, combining different geometric shapes, and real-world applications
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced area calculation skills and geometric reasoning

learning_outcomes.description: Apply area calculation skills to complex geometric problems, including composite shapes and contextual mathematical challenges
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Comprehensive understanding of area calculation and geometric principles

learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate advanced problem-solving skills in area calculation, including complex geometric shapes, scale drawings, and mathematical reasoning
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Comprehensive geometric and algebraic skills

reasoning:
The learning outcomes for Capacity in Mathematics will progressively develop students' understanding of volume, measurement, and comparative skills. The progression will focus on moving from concrete, sensory experiences in early years to more abstract and precise measurements in later years. The outcomes will build spatial awareness, measurement skills, and mathematical reasoning related to capacity.

Key developmental considerations:
- Junior and Senior Infants: Sensory exploration and basic comparative skills
- First and Second Class: Introduction to standard and non-standard units
- Third and Fourth Class: More precise measurements and conversions
- Fifth and Sixth Class: Complex problem-solving and real-world applications of capacity measurement

learning_outcomes.description: Explore and compare the capacity of different containers using direct comparison and non-standard units
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic understanding of more/less concepts

learning_outcomes.description: Estimate and measure capacity using non-standard units like cups, spoons, and simple containers
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Ability to compare container sizes

learning_outcomes.description: Measure and record capacity using standard units (millilitres) and perform simple additions and subtractions
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of non-standard measurement

learning_outcomes.description: Convert between millilitres and litres, and solve simple word problems involving capacity
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic millilitre measurements

learning_outcomes.description: Perform complex conversions between millilitres and litres, and solve multi-step capacity problems
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of metric conversions

learning_outcomes.description: Apply capacity measurements to real-world contexts, including cooking recipes and scientific measurements
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced metric conversion skills

learning_outcomes.description: Analyze and interpret capacity data, create capacity-related graphs, and solve complex measurement problems
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Comprehensive understanding of metric measurements

learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate advanced problem-solving skills using capacity measurements in interdisciplinary contexts
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced mathematical reasoning and measurement skills

reasoning:
The learning outcomes for Length will progressively develop students' understanding of measurement, starting from basic comparison and non-standard units to more precise measurements using standard units. The progression will focus on developing spatial awareness, estimation skills, and accurate measurement techniques appropriate to each developmental stage.

Key developmental considerations:
- Junior and Senior Infants: Foundational perceptual skills
- First and Second Class: Introduction to basic measurement concepts
- Third and Fourth Class: More precise measurements and unit conversions
- Fifth and Sixth Class: Advanced measurement, problem-solving, and real-world applications

learning_outcomes.description: Compare and describe lengths of objects using comparative language like 'longer', 'shorter', and 'same length'
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic understanding of spatial relationships

learning_outcomes.description: Use non-standard units (like paper clips or pencils) to measure and compare the length of different objects
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Ability to align objects and count

learning_outcomes.description: Measure and record lengths using standard units (centimetres) with increasing accuracy
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of non-standard measurement

learning_outcomes.description: Estimate and measure lengths in centimetres and metres, understanding the relationship between these units
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic measurement skills with centimetres

learning_outcomes.description: Convert between centimetres and metres, and solve simple measurement problems involving length
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of metric units and basic conversions

learning_outcomes.description: Use millimetres in precise measurements and perform complex conversions between millimetres, centimetres, and metres
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced understanding of metric length units

learning_outcomes.description: Apply measurement skills to real-world contexts, including perimeter calculations and scale drawings
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Comprehensive understanding of length measurements and conversions

learning_outcomes.description: Solve complex measurement problems involving length, including multi-step calculations and contextual applications
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced measurement and conversion skills

reasoning:
The learning outcomes for the Money strand will progressively develop students' understanding of currency, value, calculation, and financial literacy. The progression will focus on:
1. Recognition and identification of coins and notes
2. Understanding the value of money
3. Basic monetary calculations
4. Practical money management skills
5. Increasing complexity of financial reasoning

The outcomes will build mathematical skills while also introducing practical life skills, ensuring that students develop both conceptual understanding and real-world application of monetary concepts.

learning_outcomes.description: Recognize and name Irish coins and notes, identifying their basic visual characteristics
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic counting skills

learning_outcomes.description: Identify the value of different coins and perform simple matching of coin values
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Ability to recognize coins from Junior Infants

learning_outcomes.description: Add and subtract small monetary amounts using coins up to €2, demonstrating understanding of basic money calculations
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Knowledge of coin values from Senior Infants

learning_outcomes.description: Calculate change from simple purchases using amounts up to €10, rounding to nearest euro
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic addition and subtraction skills with money

learning_outcomes.description: Solve multi-step money problems involving addition, subtraction, and simple percentage calculations
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of monetary calculations from previous years

learning_outcomes.description: Develop and explain budgeting strategies, calculating total costs, discounts, and comparing prices
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced money calculation skills

learning_outcomes.description: Apply complex financial reasoning to real-world scenarios, including understanding of saving, simple interest, and cost comparisons
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Comprehensive money management skills

learning_outcomes.description: Analyze and present financial scenarios, demonstrating advanced understanding of monetary concepts, budgeting, and financial decision-making
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced financial reasoning skills from previous years

reasoning:
The learning outcomes for the Time strand will progressively develop students' understanding of time concepts, moving from basic temporal awareness to more complex time-related skills. The progression will focus on:
1. Developing initial time awareness and vocabulary
2. Understanding time measurement tools and units
3. Reading and interpreting time in various formats
4. Solving time-related problems
5. Applying time concepts to real-world situations

The outcomes will build complexity incrementally, ensuring age-appropriate cognitive development and mathematical understanding.

learning_outcomes.description: Recognize and use basic time-related vocabulary such as 'morning', 'afternoon', 'evening', and 'night'
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: None

learning_outcomes.description: Sequence daily events in order and understand simple concepts of before and after
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic time-related vocabulary

learning_outcomes.description: Read and write time to the hour and half-hour on analog and digital clocks
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of sequential time and basic clock structure

learning_outcomes.description: Read and write time to the quarter-hour on analog and digital clocks, and understand the relationship between hours and minutes
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Ability to read time to the hour and half-hour

learning_outcomes.description: Calculate duration of time intervals, convert between hours, minutes, and seconds, and solve simple time-related word problems
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Ability to read time to the quarter-hour

learning_outcomes.description: Use 24-hour clock notation, calculate time differences, and solve complex time-related problems involving multiple time zones or elapsed time
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of time intervals and conversions

learning_outcomes.description: Apply time concepts to real-world scenarios, including scheduling, time management, and interpreting time-based data and graphs
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Comprehensive understanding of time measurement and calculations

learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate advanced understanding of time concepts, including calculating time across international date lines, understanding leap years, and solving complex multi-step time-related problems
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced time calculation and application skills

reasoning:
The learning outcomes for Weight in Mathematics will progressively develop students' understanding of measurement, from basic sensory experiences in early years to more precise and abstract measurements in later primary years. The progression will focus on developing conceptual understanding, practical skills, and problem-solving abilities related to weight measurement.

Key developmental considerations:
- Junior and Senior Infants: Sensory exploration and basic comparative skills
- First and Second Class: Introduction to standard units and basic measurement tools
- Third and Fourth Class: More precise measurements and simple calculations
- Fifth and Sixth Class: Advanced understanding, complex problem-solving, and real-world applications

learning_outcomes.description: Explore and compare the weight of different objects using non-standard language like 'heavy' and 'light'
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic sensory awareness

learning_outcomes.description: Compare and order objects by weight using simple balance scales and descriptive terms
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic weight comparison skills

learning_outcomes.description: Measure and record weights using standard units (grams) and simple weighing instruments
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of basic weight comparisons

learning_outcomes.description: Estimate, measure, and record weights of objects using grams and kilograms with increasing accuracy
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic measurement skills with grams

learning_outcomes.description: Perform simple weight conversions between grams and kilograms and solve practical measurement problems
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Accurate measurement skills and understanding of units

learning_outcomes.description: Apply weight measurement skills to real-world contexts, including multi-step problem-solving involving different units
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Confident weight measurement and conversion skills

learning_outcomes.description: Analyze and interpret weight-related data, perform complex conversions, and solve sophisticated measurement problems
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced understanding of weight measurement principles

learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate comprehensive understanding of weight measurement, including advanced problem-solving, metric conversions, and application in scientific and practical contexts
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Mastery of weight measurement concepts and skills

reasoning: The learning outcomes for Comparing and Ordering in Mathematics will progressively develop students' understanding of numerical relationships, moving from basic comparison skills to more complex numerical reasoning. The progression will focus on developing mathematical language, conceptual understanding, and the ability to manipulate and compare numbers with increasing sophistication across primary school years.

learning_outcomes.description: Identify and compare small quantities using concrete materials, recognizing which group has more, less, or the same number of objects
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic understanding of counting

learning_outcomes.description: Compare and order numbers up to 20, using comparative language such as 'greater than', 'less than', and 'equal to'
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Ability to count to 20 and recognize number symbols

learning_outcomes.description: Order and compare whole numbers up to 100, using number lines and place value understanding
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Knowledge of numbers up to 50 and basic place value concepts

learning_outcomes.description: Compare and order whole numbers up to 1000, using place value and understanding of magnitude
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Solid understanding of place value to 100 and number comparison strategies

learning_outcomes.description: Compare, order, and represent whole numbers up to 10,000, using multiple strategies including number lines, place value, and symbolic notation
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Confident understanding of place value to 1000 and number comparison techniques

learning_outcomes.description: Compare and order whole numbers, decimals, and simple fractions, demonstrating understanding of relative magnitude and advanced comparison strategies
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Ability to work with whole numbers up to 10,000 and basic fraction concepts

learning_outcomes.description: Compare, order, and interpret whole numbers, decimals, and fractions using multiple representations and advanced mathematical reasoning
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Comprehensive understanding of number systems and comparison techniques

learning_outcomes.description: Critically compare and order complex number types including whole numbers, decimals, fractions, and percentages, applying sophisticated mathematical reasoning and problem-solving strategies
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced understanding of number systems and comparative techniques

reasoning: The learning outcomes for Counting and Numeration will progressively develop mathematical understanding from concrete to more abstract representations, building foundational numeracy skills. The progression will focus on developing number sense, understanding place value, and expanding counting capabilities across different contexts and number ranges.

learning_outcomes.description: Recognize and count numbers from 0-10 using concrete materials and visual representations
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic understanding of numbers as quantities

learning_outcomes.description: Count forward and backward within 20, and recognize number patterns up to 20
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Ability to count numbers 0-10

learning_outcomes.description: Count, read, and write numbers up to 100, understanding place value of tens and ones
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Counting skills up to 20

learning_outcomes.description: Count, read, and write numbers up to 200, demonstrating understanding of place value and number relationships
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Counting skills up to 100

learning_outcomes.description: Count, read, and write numbers up to 1,000, explaining place value of hundreds, tens, and ones
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of place value up to 200

learning_outcomes.description: Count, read, and write numbers up to 10,000, understanding complex place value and number relationships
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Counting skills up to 1,000

learning_outcomes.description: Count, read, and write numbers up to 100,000, interpreting and representing large numbers in various contexts
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of place value up to 10,000

learning_outcomes.description: Count, read, and write numbers up to 1,000,000, demonstrating advanced understanding of place value and number systems
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Counting skills up to 100,000

reasoning: Decimals are an advanced mathematical concept that requires a gradual, scaffolded approach. The learning progression will focus on developing understanding from concrete to abstract representations, ensuring students build conceptual knowledge incrementally. The outcomes will move from basic recognition and representation to more complex operations and applications of decimals across different contexts.

learning_outcomes.description: Recognize and represent decimals to one decimal place in practical contexts, such as measuring length or weight
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Strong understanding of whole numbers and basic fractions

learning_outcomes.description: Compare and order decimals to two decimal places, understanding their relative magnitude
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Ability to recognize and represent decimals to one decimal place

learning_outcomes.description: Perform addition and subtraction of decimals to two decimal places, with and without digital tools
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of decimal place value and comparison

learning_outcomes.description: Multiply and divide decimals by whole numbers and simple decimal factors, applying strategies for estimation and checking results
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Proficiency in addition and subtraction of decimals

reasoning: The learning outcomes for Fractions will be designed to progressively build mathematical understanding from concrete to more abstract representations, ensuring age-appropriate complexity and scaffolded learning across primary school years. The progression will focus on developing fraction concepts from simple sharing and recognition to more complex operations and understanding.

learning_outcomes.description: Recognize and demonstrate simple equal sharing of objects into two or four equal parts
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic counting skills and understanding of whole objects

learning_outcomes.description: Identify and name halves and quarters in practical contexts using concrete materials
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Ability to recognize equal and unequal parts

learning_outcomes.description: Represent halves, quarters, and thirds using visual models and simple fraction notation
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of equal parts and basic fraction recognition

learning_outcomes.description: Compare and order simple fractions with like denominators, understanding fractions as parts of a whole
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Ability to represent fractions visually and understand fraction notation

learning_outcomes.description: Add and subtract simple fractions with like denominators, and recognize equivalent fractions
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of fraction representation and comparison

learning_outcomes.description: Perform addition and subtraction of fractions with different denominators using common multiples
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Skills in finding equivalent fractions and basic fraction operations

learning_outcomes.description: Multiply and divide fractions by whole numbers, and solve multi-step fraction word problems
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced fraction manipulation and understanding of fraction operations

learning_outcomes.description: Apply complex fraction operations including multiplication and division of fractions, and solve real-world mathematical problems involving fractions
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Comprehensive understanding of fraction concepts and operations

reasoning:
The learning outcomes for Number Theory will progressively develop students' understanding of number concepts, relationships, and properties. The progression will focus on building foundational mathematical thinking, moving from concrete to more abstract representations of numbers, and developing increasingly sophisticated number sense across primary school years.

Key developmental considerations:
- Junior and Senior Infants: Focus on basic number recognition and counting
- First and Second Class: Introduction to place value and basic number relationships
- Third and Fourth Class: More complex number operations and understanding of number properties
- Fifth and Sixth Class: Advanced number theory concepts, including factors, multiples, and more sophisticated number relationships

learning_outcomes.description: Recognize and count numbers from 0 to 10 using concrete materials and visual representations
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic understanding of counting

learning_outcomes.description: Identify and represent numbers up to 20, understanding one-to-one correspondence and basic number relationships
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Ability to count to 10

learning_outcomes.description: Understand place value for two-digit numbers and represent numbers using tens and ones
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic number recognition and counting skills

learning_outcomes.description: Explore number patterns, recognize even and odd numbers, and understand basic number properties
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of place value and basic number relationships

learning_outcomes.description: Identify and explain factors and multiples of numbers up to 100, and understand prime and composite numbers
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Knowledge of number patterns and basic multiplication

learning_outcomes.description: Apply understanding of factors, multiples, and prime numbers to solve complex number problems and investigate number relationships
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of factors and multiples

learning_outcomes.description: Explore advanced number theory concepts including divisibility rules, prime factorization, and complex number patterns
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Comprehensive understanding of factors and multiples

learning_outcomes.description: Analyze and solve complex number theory problems, demonstrating deep understanding of number relationships, properties, and advanced mathematical reasoning
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced number theory knowledge from previous years

reasoning: The learning outcomes for Addition operations will progressively develop students' understanding of number manipulation, starting from basic counting and combining small numbers to more complex multi-digit addition with regrouping and problem-solving strategies. The progression will focus on developing computational skills, number sense, and mathematical reasoning appropriate to each developmental stage.

learning_outcomes.description: Combine small groups of objects by counting and adding numbers up to 5
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic understanding of counting individual objects

learning_outcomes.description: Add single-digit numbers within 10 using concrete materials and visual representations
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Ability to count objects and recognize number symbols

learning_outcomes.description: Perform addition of two-digit numbers without regrouping, using mental strategies and written methods
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of place value and single-digit addition

learning_outcomes.description: Add two-digit numbers with regrouping, explaining the process of carrying over
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Proficiency in adding single-digit and two-digit numbers without regrouping

learning_outcomes.description: Add three-digit numbers with and without regrouping, using efficient mental and written strategies
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Confident manipulation of two-digit addition with regrouping

learning_outcomes.description: Solve multi-step addition problems involving whole numbers, decimals, and money calculations
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Solid understanding of multi-digit addition and decimal place value

learning_outcomes.description: Apply addition strategies to solve complex real-world mathematical problems involving multiple steps and different number representations
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced understanding of addition across whole numbers and decimals

learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate advanced addition skills including working with large numbers, algebraic expressions, and applying addition in complex problem-solving contexts
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Comprehensive understanding of addition principles and strategies

reasoning: The learning outcomes for Division will progressively develop from basic sharing and grouping concepts to more complex division strategies, reflecting the cognitive development and mathematical understanding of students across primary school years. The progression will focus on building conceptual understanding, moving from concrete to abstract representations, and developing computational fluency with division.

learning_outcomes.description: Explore simple sharing of objects equally into groups through play-based activities
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic counting skills and understanding of whole numbers

learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate equal sharing of small sets of objects into groups of 2 or 3
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Ability to count and recognize small quantities

learning_outcomes.description: Understand division as fair sharing and grouping, using concrete materials to divide numbers up to 20
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic addition and subtraction skills, understanding of whole numbers

learning_outcomes.description: Perform division of two-digit numbers by single-digit divisors with and without remainders
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Multiplication tables up to 5, understanding of division concept

learning_outcomes.description: Apply division strategies for two and three-digit numbers, including interpreting and solving word problems involving division
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Multiplication tables up to 12, understanding of division with remainders

learning_outcomes.description: Solve complex division problems involving multi-digit numbers, decimals, and develop efficient mental division strategies
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced multiplication skills, understanding of division algorithms

learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate advanced division skills including long division, division of decimals, and application in real-world mathematical contexts
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Comprehensive understanding of division algorithms and decimal operations

learning_outcomes.description: Apply sophisticated division strategies to solve complex mathematical problems, including multi-step division and contextual applications
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced understanding of division, decimals, and algebraic thinking

reasoning:
The learning outcomes for Multiplication will progressively develop from basic conceptual understanding to more complex multiplicative reasoning. The progression will focus on building multiplicative thinking, understanding the relationship between repeated addition and multiplication, and developing fluency with multiplication facts and strategies.

Key developmental considerations:
- Junior and Senior Infants: Foundational understanding of grouping and equal sets
- First and Second Class: Introduction to multiplication as repeated addition
- Third and Fourth Class: Developing multiplication facts and mental strategies
- Fifth and Sixth Class: Advanced multiplication, including multi-digit numbers and problem-solving

learning_outcomes.description: Recognize and create equal groups of objects through simple sorting and sharing activities
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic counting skills and understanding of one-to-one correspondence

learning_outcomes.description: Understand multiplication as repeated addition of equal groups up to 5
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Ability to count and group objects

learning_outcomes.description: Recall and use multiplication facts for the 2, 5, and 10 times tables
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of multiplication as repeated addition

learning_outcomes.description: Multiply single-digit and two-digit numbers by 2, 3, 4, 5, and 10 using mental and written strategies
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Multiplication facts for 2, 5, and 10 times tables

learning_outcomes.description: Multiply multi-digit numbers by single-digit numbers using efficient written methods and develop strategies for mental multiplication
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of place value and multiplication facts

learning_outcomes.description: Apply multiplication skills to solve complex multi-step word problems involving whole numbers and decimal numbers
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Proficiency with multi-digit multiplication and problem-solving strategies

learning_outcomes.description: Use multiplication of fractions and decimals in contextual problem-solving situations
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of fraction and decimal concepts

learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate advanced multiplicative reasoning by solving complex real-world problems involving proportional thinking and scaling
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Comprehensive understanding of multiplication across different number types

reasoning:
The learning outcomes for subtraction will progressively develop from basic concrete understanding to more complex abstract operations. The progression will focus on:
1. Initial concept of taking away
2. Developing mental subtraction strategies
3. Handling larger numbers
4. Introducing regrouping and borrowing
5. Applying subtraction in real-world contexts

The outcomes will build mathematical thinking, problem-solving skills, and computational fluency while ensuring age-appropriate complexity and cognitive development.

learning_outcomes.description: Recognize and demonstrate subtraction as 'taking away' using concrete materials and visual representations
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic counting skills, understanding of numbers 0-10

learning_outcomes.description: Subtract single-digit numbers within 10 using manipulatives and begin simple mental subtraction strategies
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of subtraction as taking away, familiarity with numbers 0-10

learning_outcomes.description: Subtract two-digit numbers with and without regrouping, using concrete and pictorial methods
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic subtraction skills, understanding of place value to 99

learning_outcomes.description: Perform subtraction of two and three-digit numbers with regrouping, developing efficient mental and written strategies
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Subtraction skills with two-digit numbers, understanding of place value

learning_outcomes.description: Solve complex subtraction problems involving multi-digit numbers, decimals, and apply subtraction in real-world mathematical contexts
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Confident subtraction skills, understanding of place value to thousands

learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate advanced subtraction skills including multi-step problems, estimation, and applying subtraction across different mathematical scenarios
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Comprehensive understanding of subtraction with whole numbers and decimals

learning_outcomes.description: Apply sophisticated subtraction strategies to solve complex mathematical problems involving whole numbers, decimals, and algebraic contexts
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced understanding of number operations and mathematical reasoning

learning_outcomes.description: Critically analyze and solve advanced multi-step subtraction problems, demonstrating flexible mathematical thinking and strategic problem-solving
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Comprehensive mathematical skills across number operations

reasoning:
Percentages are an advanced mathematical concept that requires foundational understanding of fractions, decimals, and proportional reasoning. The progression of learning outcomes will reflect the gradual complexity of understanding percentages, starting with basic conceptual understanding and moving towards more sophisticated applications.

The learning outcomes are designed to:
1. Introduce the concept of percentages gradually
2. Build on prior knowledge of fractions and division
3. Develop practical application skills
4. Increase cognitive complexity with age
5. Align with cognitive development stages of primary school students

Key developmental considerations:
- Early years focus on conceptual understanding
- Middle primary years introduce basic calculations
- Later primary years emphasize real-world applications and more complex percentage problems

learning_outcomes.description: Understand the basic concept of percentage as 'out of 100' and recognize percentage symbols and notation
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic understanding of fractions and division

learning_outcomes.description: Calculate simple percentages of whole numbers and recognize common percentages (50%, 25%, 10%) in practical contexts
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of percentage as a concept, basic multiplication skills

learning_outcomes.description: Convert between fractions, decimals, and percentages, and solve multi-step percentage problems involving discounts and increases
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Knowledge of fraction and decimal representations, multiplication and division skills

learning_outcomes.description: Apply percentage calculations to real-world scenarios including financial contexts, such as calculating profit, interest, and percentage change
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced percentage conversion and calculation skills

reasoning:
Place value is a fundamental mathematical concept that develops progressively through primary education. The learning outcomes are designed to build complexity and understanding incrementally, starting with basic number recognition and gradually advancing to more sophisticated manipulation of multi-digit numbers. The progression reflects cognitive development stages and increasing mathematical abstraction.

Key developmental considerations:
- Junior and Senior Infants focus on foundational number sense
- Early primary years (1st-2nd) introduce place value concepts concretely
- Middle primary (3rd-4th) expand to larger numbers and more complex representations
- Senior primary (5th-6th) develop advanced place value understanding and strategic manipulation

learning_outcomes.description: Recognize and count numbers from 0-10 sequentially
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic number recognition

learning_outcomes.description: Understand and represent numbers up to 20 using concrete materials to show tens and ones
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Ability to count to 10

learning_outcomes.description: Read, write, and represent numbers up to 100, demonstrating understanding of tens and ones
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic number representation skills

learning_outcomes.description: Compare and order numbers up to 999, explaining the value of each digit in a three-digit number
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of two-digit number place value

learning_outcomes.description: Understand and explain place value for numbers up to 10,000, including thousands, hundreds, tens, and ones
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Proficiency with three-digit number place value

learning_outcomes.description: Interpret and manipulate numbers up to 100,000, demonstrating advanced understanding of place value relationships
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Comprehensive understanding of four-digit number place value

learning_outcomes.description: Apply place value understanding to solve complex mathematical problems involving decimals and large numbers
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced place value knowledge for whole numbers

learning_outcomes.description: Critically analyze and solve multi-step problems using advanced place value concepts, including scientific notation
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Comprehensive understanding of whole number and decimal place value

reasoning:
The learning outcomes for 2-D shapes will progressively develop spatial reasoning, shape recognition, and geometric understanding from Junior Infants through Sixth Class. The progression will focus on increasing complexity of shape identification, properties, classification, and application, aligning with children's cognitive development and mathematical reasoning skills.

Key developmental considerations:
- Junior and Senior Infants: Basic shape recognition and naming
- First and Second Class: Exploring shape properties and simple classifications
- Third and Fourth Class: More advanced shape analysis and geometric relationships
- Fifth and Sixth Class: Complex geometric reasoning and practical applications

learning_outcomes.description: Identify and name basic 2-D shapes (circle, square, triangle, rectangle) in the environment
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: None

learning_outcomes.description: Recognize and draw basic 2-D shapes, describing their simple characteristics (number of sides, corners)
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Ability to identify basic shapes

learning_outcomes.description: Compare and sort 2-D shapes based on their properties (number of sides, symmetry, angles)
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of basic shape characteristics

learning_outcomes.description: Classify 2-D shapes into groups and explain the reasoning for their classification
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Ability to identify shape properties

learning_outcomes.description: Investigate and describe the properties of regular and irregular 2-D shapes, including parallel and perpendicular lines
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of shape classification

learning_outcomes.description: Analyze and construct 2-D shapes with specific geometric properties, using mathematical reasoning and drawing tools
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced understanding of shape properties

learning_outcomes.description: Apply knowledge of 2-D shapes to solve complex geometric problems and create mathematical models
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Comprehensive understanding of shape characteristics and relationships

learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate advanced geometric reasoning by exploring transformations, symmetry, and complex relationships between 2-D shapes
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Comprehensive geometric knowledge from previous years

reasoning:
The learning outcomes for 3-D shapes will progressively develop spatial awareness, shape recognition, and geometric reasoning skills across primary school years. The progression will focus on:
1. Initial shape recognition and basic exploration in early years
2. Developing vocabulary and classification skills
3. Understanding properties of 3-D shapes
4. Advanced geometric reasoning and problem-solving in later years

The outcomes will build complexity, moving from simple identification to more sophisticated spatial reasoning and mathematical thinking about three-dimensional objects.

learning_outcomes.description: Identify and name basic 3-D shapes like sphere, cube, and cylinder in the environment
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic visual recognition skills

learning_outcomes.description: Sort and group 3-D shapes based on simple observable characteristics like round or flat surfaces
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Ability to identify basic 3-D shapes

learning_outcomes.description: Describe the properties of 3-D shapes including number of faces, edges, and vertices for common shapes like cube and cuboid
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic shape recognition and sorting skills

learning_outcomes.description: Compare and contrast different 3-D shapes, explaining their geometric properties and how they differ from 2-D shapes
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of basic 3-D shape properties

learning_outcomes.description: Construct and draw nets for simple 3-D shapes, understanding how 2-D representations can create 3-D objects
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Knowledge of shape properties and spatial relationships

learning_outcomes.description: Analyze and calculate surface area and volume of rectangular prisms and other regular 3-D shapes
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of shape properties and basic measurement

learning_outcomes.description: Apply geometric reasoning to solve complex problems involving 3-D shapes, including transformations and symmetry
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced understanding of 3-D shape properties

learning_outcomes.description: Investigate and explain relationships between different 3-D shapes, demonstrating advanced spatial reasoning and mathematical thinking
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Comprehensive knowledge of 3-D geometric concepts

reasoning:
The learning outcomes for Lines and Angles will progressively develop spatial reasoning, geometric understanding, and measurement skills across primary school years. The progression will focus on:
1. Initial recognition and basic identification in Junior and Senior Infants
2. Developing understanding of line types and basic angle concepts in early primary years
3. Introducing more complex angle measurements and geometric relationships in middle primary
4. Advanced geometric reasoning and precise angle calculations in senior primary years

The outcomes will build complexity, moving from concrete, visual experiences to more abstract mathematical thinking about lines and angles.

learning_outcomes.description: Recognize and point out straight and curved lines in the immediate environment
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic visual perception skills

learning_outcomes.description: Identify and draw different types of lines (horizontal, vertical, diagonal) using drawing tools
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic line recognition from Junior Infants

learning_outcomes.description: Understand and demonstrate the difference between parallel and intersecting lines using geometric shapes
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Ability to draw and recognize basic line types

learning_outcomes.description: Recognize and classify right angles, identifying them in everyday objects and simple geometric shapes
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of line types and basic spatial relationships

learning_outcomes.description: Estimate and measure angles using a protractor, distinguishing between acute, right, and obtuse angles
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Familiarity with right angles and basic geometric shapes

learning_outcomes.description: Calculate and construct angles, understanding the relationship between adjacent and vertically opposite angles
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Ability to measure angles with a protractor

learning_outcomes.description: Analyze and solve complex geometric problems involving angle relationships in polygons and triangles
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced understanding of angle measurement and properties

learning_outcomes.description: Apply advanced geometric reasoning to solve real-world problems involving angle calculations and transformations
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Comprehensive understanding of angle properties and geometric relationships

reasoning: The learning outcomes for Position and Direction in Mathematics will progressively develop spatial awareness, directional language, and navigational skills. The progression will focus on increasing complexity of spatial understanding, from basic positional concepts to more advanced navigational and coordinate-based skills. The outcomes will build spatial reasoning, geometric thinking, and practical application of directional knowledge.

learning_outcomes.description: Identify and describe basic position words such as 'on', 'under', 'beside', 'between', and 'next to' using concrete objects and personal positioning
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: None

learning_outcomes.description: Use directional language to describe movement and position, including 'left', 'right', 'forward', and 'backward' in simple spatial contexts
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic understanding of positional vocabulary

learning_outcomes.description: Follow and give simple directional instructions using cardinal directions (north, south, east, west) in classroom and playground settings
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of basic directional language

learning_outcomes.description: Create and interpret simple maps with basic symbols, demonstrating understanding of relative position and directional orientation
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Knowledge of cardinal directions and positional vocabulary

learning_outcomes.description: Use grid references and coordinate systems to describe and locate positions on simple maps and grids
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of map symbols and directional concepts

learning_outcomes.description: Apply geometric transformations like translation, rotation, and reflection to understand and describe position and movement
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Knowledge of coordinate systems and spatial relationships

learning_outcomes.description: Solve complex navigational problems using advanced coordinate geometry, including scale, proportion, and multi-step directional challenges
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced understanding of coordinate systems and transformations

learning_outcomes.description: Analyze and interpret complex spatial scenarios, using advanced coordinate geometry to solve real-world positioning and navigation problems
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Comprehensive understanding of spatial reasoning and coordinate systems

reasoning:
The learning outcomes for Symmetry will progress from basic visual recognition and exploration in early years to more complex understanding and application of symmetry principles in later primary years. The progression will focus on developing spatial awareness, geometric reasoning, and the ability to identify, create, and manipulate symmetrical shapes and patterns.

Key developmental considerations:
- Junior and Senior Infants: Sensory exploration and basic visual recognition
- First and Second Class: Hands-on identification and simple symmetry creation
- Third and Fourth Class: More advanced symmetry concepts and mathematical reasoning
- Fifth and Sixth Class: Complex symmetry applications and transformational understanding

learning_outcomes.description: Recognize and explore simple symmetrical shapes through visual and tactile experiences
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: None

learning_outcomes.description: Identify lines of symmetry in basic shapes and everyday objects through guided activities
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Basic shape recognition

learning_outcomes.description: Create and draw symmetrical patterns and shapes using folding, cutting, and drawing techniques
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of basic symmetry concepts

learning_outcomes.description: Explore and describe different types of symmetry (line and rotational) in geometric shapes and patterns
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Ability to identify lines of symmetry

learning_outcomes.description: Analyze and construct symmetrical designs using mathematical tools and precise measurements
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Understanding of line and rotational symmetry

learning_outcomes.description: Apply symmetry principles to solve complex geometric problems and create intricate symmetrical designs
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced understanding of symmetry types and properties

learning_outcomes.description: Investigate and explain advanced symmetry concepts, including transformational symmetry and symmetry in nature and art
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Comprehensive knowledge of symmetry principles

learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate sophisticated understanding of symmetry by creating complex mathematical and artistic symmetrical representations
learning_outcomes.prerequisites: Advanced symmetry knowledge and skills
